t: Mark 1
John the Baptist Prepares the Way
The*p beginning of the good news about Jesus the Messiah, the Son of God,
as it is written in Isaiah the prophet: “I*pn will send my messenger ahead of you, who*ld will prepare your way”—
“a*ln voice of one calling in the wilderness, ‘Prepare*ln the way for the Lord, make*ld straight paths for him.’ ”
And*p so John the Baptist appeared in the wilderness, preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
The whole Judean countryside and all the people of Jerusalem went out to him. Confessing their sins, they were baptized by him in the Jordan River.
John wore clothing made of camel’s hair, with a leather belt around his waist, and he ate locusts and wild honey.
And this was his message: “After me comes the one more powerful than I, the straps of whose sandals I am not worthy to stoop down and untie.
I baptize you with water, but he will baptize you with the Holy Spirit.”
The Baptism and Testing of Jesus
At*p that time Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized by John in the Jordan.
Just as Jesus was coming up out of the water, he saw heaven being torn open and the Spirit descending on him like a dove.
And a voice came from heaven: “You are my Son, whom I love; with you I am well pleased.”
At*p once the Spirit sent him out into the wilderness,
and he was in the wilderness forty days, being tempted by Satan. He was with the wild animals, and angels attended him.
Jesus Announces the Good News
After*p John was put in prison, Jesus went into Galilee, proclaiming the good news of God.
“The*r time*r has*r come,”*r he said. “The*r kingdom*r of*r God*r has*r come*r near.*r Repent*r and*r believe*r the*r good*r news!”*r
Jesus Calls His First Disciples
As*p Jesus walked beside the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and his brother Andrew casting a net into the lake, for they were fishermen.
“Come,*r follow*r me,”*r Jesus said, “and*r I*r will*r send*r you*r out*r to*r fish*r for*r people.”*r
At once they left their nets and followed him.
When*p he had gone a little farther, he saw James son of Zebedee and his brother John in a boat, preparing their nets.
Without delay he called them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hired men and followed him.
Jesus Drives Out an Impure Spirit
They*p went to Capernaum, and when the Sabbath came, Jesus went into the synagogue and began to teach.
The people were amazed at his teaching, because he taught them as one who had authority, not as the teachers of the law.
Just then a man in their synagogue who was possessed by an impure spirit cried out,
“What do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are—the Holy One of God!”
“Be*rp quiet!”*r said Jesus sternly. “Come*r out*r of*r him!”*r
The impure spirit shook the man violently and came out of him with a shriek.
The*p people were all so amazed that they asked each other, “What is this? A new teaching—and with authority! He even gives orders to impure spirits and they obey him.”
News about him spread quickly over the whole region of Galilee.
Jesus Heals Many
As*p soon as they left the synagogue, they went with James and John to the home of Simon and Andrew.
Simon’s mother-in-law was in bed with a fever, and they immediately told Jesus about her.
So he went to her, took her hand and helped her up. The fever left her and she began to wait on them.
That*p evening after sunset the people brought to Jesus all the sick and demon-possessed.
The whole town gathered at the door,
and Jesus healed many who had various diseases. He also drove out many demons, but he would not let the demons speak because they knew who he was.
Jesus Prays in a Solitary Place
Very*p early in the morning, while it was still dark, Jesus got up, left the house and went off to a solitary place, where he prayed.
Simon and his companions went to look for him,
and when they found him, they exclaimed: “Everyone is looking for you!”
Jesus*p replied, “Let*r us*r go*r somewhere*r else—to*r the*r nearby*r villages—so*r I*r can*r preach*r there*r also.*r That*r is*r why*r I*r have*r come.”*r
So he traveled throughout Galilee, preaching in their synagogues and driving out demons.
Jesus Heals a Man With Leprosy
A*p man with leprosy came to him and begged him on his knees, “If you are willing, you can make me clean.”
Jesus*p was indignant. He reached out his hand and touched the man. “I*r am*r willing,”*r he said. “Be*r clean!”*r
Immediately the leprosy left him and he was cleansed.
Jesus*p sent him away at once with a strong warning:

“See*r that*r you*r don’t*r tell*r this*r to*r anyone.*r But*r go,*r show*r yourself*r to*r the*r priest*r and*r offer*r the*r sacrifices*r that*r Moses*r commanded*r for*r your*r cleansing,*r as*r a*r testimony*r to*r them.”*r

Instead he went out and began to talk freely, spreading the news. As a result, Jesus could no longer enter a town openly but stayed outside in lonely places. Yet the people still came to him from everywhere.
Mark 2
Jesus Forgives and Heals a Paralyzed Man
A*p few days later, when Jesus again entered Capernaum, the people heard that he had come home.
They gathered in such large numbers that there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the word to them.
Some men came, bringing to him a paralyzed man, carried by four of them.
Since they could not get him to Jesus because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on.
When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralyzed man, “Son,*r your*r sins*r are*r forgiven.”*r
Now*p some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to themselves,
“Why does this fellow talk like that? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?”
Immediately*p Jesus knew in his spirit that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to them, “Why*r are*r you*r thinking*r these*r things?*r
Which*r is*r easier:*r to*r say*r to*r this*r paralyzed*r man,*r ‘Your*r sins*r are*r forgiven,’*r or*r to*r say,*r ‘Get*r up,*r take*r your*r mat*r and*r walk’?*r
But*r I*r want*r you*r to*r know*r that*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r has*r authority*r on*r earth*r to*r forgive*r sins.”*r So he said to the man,
“I*r tell*r you,*r get*r up,*r take*r your*r mat*r and*r go*r home.”*r
He got up, took his mat and walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they praised God, saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”
Jesus Calls Levi and Eats With Sinners
Once*p again Jesus went out beside the lake. A large crowd came to him, and he began to teach them.
As he walked along, he saw Levi son of Alphaeus sitting at the tax collector’s booth. “Follow*r me,”*r Jesus told him, and Levi got up and followed him.
While*p Jesus was having dinner at Levi’s house, many tax collectors and sinners were eating with him and his disciples, for there were many who followed him.
When the teachers of the law who were Pharisees saw him eating with the sinners and tax collectors, they asked his disciples: “Why does he eat with tax collectors and sinners?”
On*p hearing this, Jesus said to them, “It*r is*r not*r the*r healthy*r who*r need*r a*r doctor,*r but*r the*r sick.*r I*r have*r not*r come*r to*r call*r the*r righteous,*r but*r sinners.”*r
Jesus Questioned About Fasting
Now*p John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting. Some people came and asked Jesus, “How is it that John’s disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees are fasting, but yours are not?”
Jesus*p answered, “How*r can*r the*r guests*r of*r the*r bridegroom*r fast*r while*r he*r is*r with*r them?*r They*r cannot,*r so*r long*r as*r they*r have*r him*r with*r them.*r
But*r the*r time*r will*r come*r when*r the*r bridegroom*r will*r be*r taken*r from*r them,*r and*r on*r that*r day*r they*r will*r fast.*r
“No*rp one*r sews*r a*r patch*r of*r unshrunk*r cloth*r on*r an*r old*r garment.*r Otherwise,*r the*r new*r piece*r will*r pull*r away*r from*r the*r old,*r making*r the*r tear*r worse.*r

And*r no*r one*r pours*r new*r wine*r into*r old*r wineskins.*r Otherwise,*r the*r wine*r will*r burst*r the*r skins,*r and*r both*r the*r wine*r and*r the*r wineskins*r will*r be*r ruined.*r No,*r they*r pour*r new*r wine*r into*r new*r wineskins.”*r
Jesus Is Lord of the Sabbath
One*p Sabbath Jesus was going through the grainfields, and as his disciples walked along, they began to pick some heads of grain.
The Pharisees said to him, “Look, why are they doing what is unlawful on the Sabbath?”
He*p answered, “Have*r you*r never*r read*r what*r David*r did*r when*r he*r and*r his*r companions*r were*r hungry*r and*r in*r need?*r

In*r the*r days*r of*r Abiathar*r the*r high*r priest,*r he*r entered*r the*r house*r of*r God*r and*r ate*r the*r consecrated*r bread,*r which*r is*r lawful*r only*r for*r priests*r to*r eat.*r And*r he*r also*r gave*r some*r to*r his*r companions.”*r
Then*p he said to them, “The*r Sabbath*r was*r made*r for*r man,*r not*r man*r for*r the*r Sabbath.*r
So*r the*r Son*r of*r Man*r is*r Lord*r even*r of*r the*r Sabbath.”*r
Mark 3
Jesus Heals on the Sabbath
Another*p time Jesus went into the synagogue, and a man with a shriveled hand was there.
Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath.
Jesus said to the man with the shriveled hand, “Stand*r up*r in*r front*r of*r everyone.”*r
Then*p Jesus asked them, “Which*r is*r lawful*r on*r the*r Sabbath:*r to*r do*r good*r or*r to*r do*r evil,*r to*r save*r life*r or*r to*r kill?”*r But they remained silent.
He*p looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch*r out*r your*r hand.”*r He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restored.
Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.
Crowds Follow Jesus
Jesus*p withdrew with his disciples to the lake, and a large crowd from Galilee followed.
When they heard about all he was doing, many people came to him from Judea, Jerusalem, Idumea, and the regions across the Jordan and around Tyre and Sidon.
Because of the crowd he told his disciples to have a small boat ready for him, to keep the people from crowding him.
For he had healed many, so that those with diseases were pushing forward to touch him.
Whenever the impure spirits saw him, they fell down before him and cried out, “You are the Son of God.”
But he gave them strict orders not to tell others about him.
Jesus Appoints the Twelve
Jesus*p went up on a mountainside and called to him those he wanted, and they came to him.
He appointed twelve that they might be with him and that he might send them out to preach
and to have authority to drive out demons.
These are the twelve he appointed: Simon (to whom he gave the name Peter),
James son of Zebedee and his brother John (to them he gave the name Boanerges,*i which means “sons of thunder”),
Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Thaddaeus, Simon the Zealot
and Judas Iscariot, who betrayed him.
Jesus Accused by His Family and by Teachers of the Law
Then*p Jesus entered a house, and again a crowd gathered, so that he and his disciples were not even able to eat.
When his family heard about this, they went to take charge of him, for they said, “He is out of his mind.”
And*p the teachers of the law who came down from Jerusalem said, “He is possessed by Beelzebul! By the prince of demons he is driving out demons.”
So*p Jesus called them over to him and began to speak to them in parables: “How*r can*r Satan*r drive*r out*r Satan?*r
If*r a*r kingdom*r is*r divided*r against*r itself,*r that*r kingdom*r cannot*r stand.*r
If*r a*r house*r is*r divided*r against*r itself,*r that*r house*r cannot*r stand.*r
And*r if*r Satan*r opposes*r himself*r and*r is*r divided,*r he*r cannot*r stand;*r his*r end*r has*r come.*r
In*r fact,*r no*r one*r can*r enter*r a*r strong*r man’s*r house*r without*r first*r tying*r him*r up.*r Then*r he*r can*r plunder*r the*r strong*r man’s*r house.*r
Truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r people*r can*r be*r forgiven*r all*r their*r sins*r and*r every*r slander*r they*r utter,*r
but*r whoever*r blasphemes*r against*r the*r Holy*r Spirit*r will*r never*r be*r forgiven;*r they*r are*r guilty*r of*r an*r eternal*r sin.”*r
He*p said this because they were saying, “He has an impure spirit.”
Then*p Jesus’ mother and brothers arrived. Standing outside, they sent someone in to call him.
A crowd was sitting around him, and they told him, “Your mother and brothers are outside looking for you.”
“Who*rp are*r my*r mother*r and*r my*r brothers?”*r he asked.
Then*p he looked at those seated in a circle around him and said, “Here*r are*r my*r mother*r and*r my*r brothers!*r
Whoever*r does*r God’s*r will*r is*r my*r brother*r and*r sister*r and*r mother.”*r
Mark 4
The Parable of the Sower

Again*p Jesus began to teach by the lake. The crowd that gathered around him was so large that he got into a boat and sat in it out on the lake, while all the people were along the shore at the water’s edge.
He taught them many things by parables, and in his teaching said:
“Listen!*r A*r farmer*r went*r out*r to*r sow*r his*r seed.*r
As*r he*r was*r scattering*r the*r seed,*r some*r fell*r along*r the*r path,*r and*r the*r birds*r came*r and*r ate*r it*r up.*r
Some*r fell*r on*r rocky*r places,*r where*r it*r did*r not*r have*r much*r soil.*r It*r sprang*r up*r quickly,*r because*r the*r soil*r was*r shallow.*r
But*r when*r the*r sun*r came*r up,*r the*r plants*r were*r scorched,*r and*r they*r withered*r because*r they*r had*r no*r root.*r
Other*r seed*r fell*r among*r thorns,*r which*r grew*r up*r and*r choked*r the*r plants,*r so*r that*r they*r did*r not*r bear*r grain.*r
Still*r other*r seed*r fell*r on*r good*r soil.*r It*r came*r up,*r grew*r and*r produced*r a*r crop,*r some*r multiplying*r thirty,*r some*r sixty,*r some*r a*r hundred*r times.”*r
Then*p Jesus said, “Whoever*r has*r ears*r to*r hear,*r let*r them*r hear.”*r
When*p he was alone, the Twelve and the others around him asked him about the parables.
He told them, “The*r secret*r of*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r has*r been*r given*r to*r you.*r But*r to*r those*r on*r the*r outside*r everything*r is*r said*r in*r parables*r
so*r that,*r “ ‘they*rpn may*r be*r ever*r seeing*r but*r never*r perceiving,*r and*rld ever*r hearing*r but*r never*r understanding;*r otherwise*rln they*r might*r turn*r and*r be*r forgiven!’”*r
Then*p Jesus said to them, “Don’t*r you*r understand*r this*r parable?*r How*r then*r will*r you*r understand*r any*r parable?*r
The*r farmer*r sows*r the*r word.*r

Some*r people*r are*r like*r seed*r along*r the*r path,*r where*r the*r word*r is*r sown.*r As*r soon*r as*r they*r hear*r it,*r Satan*r comes*r and*r takes*r away*r the*r word*r that*r was*r sown*r in*r them.*r
Others,*r like*r seed*r sown*r on*r rocky*r places,*r hear*r the*r word*r and*r at*r once*r receive*r it*r with*r joy.*r
But*r since*r they*r have*r no*r root,*r they*r last*r only*r a*r short*r time.*r When*r trouble*r or*r persecution*r comes*r because*r of*r the*r word,*r they*r quickly*r fall*r away.*r
Still*r others,*r like*r seed*r sown*r among*r thorns,*r hear*r the*r word;*r
but*r the*r worries*r of*r this*r life,*r the*r deceitfulness*r of*r wealth*r and*r the*r desires*r for*r other*r things*r come*r in*r and*r choke*r the*r word,*r making*r it*r unfruitful.*r
Others,*r like*r seed*r sown*r on*r good*r soil,*r hear*r the*r word,*r accept*r it,*r and*r produce*r a*r crop—some*r thirty,*r some*r sixty,*r some*r a*r hundred*r times*r what*r was*r sown.”*r
A Lamp on a Stand
He*p said to them, “Do*r you*r bring*r in*r a*r lamp*r to*r put*r it*r under*r a*r bowl*r or*r a*r bed?*r Instead,*r don’t*r you*r put*r it*r on*r its*r stand?*r
For*r whatever*r is*r hidden*r is*r meant*r to*r be*r disclosed,*r and*r whatever*r is*r concealed*r is*r meant*r to*r be*r brought*r out*r into*r the*r open.*r
If*r anyone*r has*r ears*r to*r hear,*r let*r them*r hear.”*r
“Consider*rp carefully*r what*r you*r hear,”*r he continued. “With*r the*r measure*r you*r use,*r it*r will*r be*r measured*r to*r you—and*r even*r more.*r
Whoever*r has*r will*r be*r given*r more;*r whoever*r does*r not*r have,*r even*r what*r they*r have*r will*r be*r taken*r from*r them.”*r
The Parable of the Growing Seed
He*p also said, “This*r is*r what*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r like.*r A*r man*r scatters*r seed*r on*r the*r ground.*r
Night*r and*r day,*r whether*r he*r sleeps*r or*r gets*r up,*r the*r seed*r sprouts*r and*r grows,*r though*r he*r does*r not*r know*r how.*r
All*r by*r itself*r the*r soil*r produces*r grain—first*r the*r stalk,*r then*r the*r head,*r then*r the*r full*r kernel*r in*r the*r head.*r
As*r soon*r as*r the*r grain*r is*r ripe,*r he*r puts*r the*r sickle*r to*r it,*r because*r the*r harvest*r has*r come.”*r
The Parable of the Mustard Seed
Again*p he said, “What*r shall*r we*r say*r the*r kingdom*r of*r God*r is*r like,*r or*r what*r parable*r shall*r we*r use*r to*r describe*r it?*r
It*r is*r like*r a*r mustard*r seed,*r which*r is*r the*r smallest*r of*r all*r seeds*r on*r earth.*r
Yet*r when*r planted,*r it*r grows*r and*r becomes*r the*r largest*r of*r all*r garden*r plants,*r with*r such*r big*r branches*r that*r the*r birds*r can*r perch*r in*r its*r shade.”*r
With*p many similar parables Jesus spoke the word to them, as much as they could understand.
He did not say anything to them without using a parable. But when he was alone with his own disciples, he explained everything.
Jesus Calms the Storm
That*p day when evening came, he said to his disciples, “Let*r us*r go*r over*r to*r the*r other*r side.”*r
Leaving the crowd behind, they took him along, just as he was, in the boat. There were also other boats with him.
A furious squall came up, and the waves broke over the boat, so that it was nearly swamped.
Jesus was in the stern, sleeping on a cushion. The disciples woke him and said to him, “Teacher, don’t you care if we drown?”
He*p got up, rebuked the wind and said to the waves, “Quiet!*r Be*r still!”*r Then the wind died down and it was completely calm.
He*p said to his disciples, “Why*r are*r you*r so*r afraid?*r Do*r you*r still*r have*r no*r faith?”*r
They*p were terrified and asked each other, “Who is this? Even the wind and the waves obey him!”
Mark 5
Jesus Restores a Demon-Possessed Man
They*p went across the lake to the region of the Gerasenes.
When Jesus got out of the boat, a man with an impure spirit came from the tombs to meet him.
This man lived in the tombs, and no one could bind him anymore, not even with a chain.
For he had often been chained hand and foot, but he tore the chains apart and broke the irons on his feet. No one was strong enough to subdue him.
Night and day among the tombs and in the hills he would cry out and cut himself with stones.
When*p he saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and fell on his knees in front of him.
He shouted at the top of his voice, “What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? In God’s name don’t torture me!”
For Jesus had said to him, “Come*r out*r of*r this*r man,*r you*r impure*r spirit!”*r
Then*p Jesus asked him, “What*r is*r your*r name?”*r “My*p name is Legion,” he replied, “for we are many.”
And he begged Jesus again and again not to send them out of the area.
A*p large herd of pigs was feeding on the nearby hillside.
The demons begged Jesus, “Send us among the pigs; allow us to go into them.”
He gave them permission, and the impure spirits came out and went into the pigs. The herd, about two thousand in number, rushed down the steep bank into the lake and were drowned.
Those*p tending the pigs ran off and reported this in the town and countryside, and the people went out to see what had happened.
When they came to Jesus, they saw the man who had been possessed by the legion of demons, sitting there, dressed and in his right mind; and they were afraid.
Those who had seen it told the people what had happened to the demon-possessed man—and told about the pigs as well.
Then the people began to plead with Jesus to leave their region.
As*p Jesus was getting into the boat, the man who had been demon-possessed begged to go with him.
Jesus did not let him, but said, “Go*r home*r to*r your*r own*r people*r and*r tell*r them*r how*r much*r the*r Lord*r has*r done*r for*r you,*r and*r how*r he*r has*r had*r mercy*r on*r you.”*r
So the man went away and began to tell in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him. And all the people were amazed.
Jesus Raises a Dead Girl and Heals a Sick Woman
When*p Jesus had again crossed over by boat to the other side of the lake, a large crowd gathered around him while he was by the lake.
Then one of the synagogue leaders, named Jairus, came, and when he saw Jesus, he fell at his feet.
He pleaded earnestly with him, “My little daughter is dying. Please come and put your hands on her so that she will be healed and live.”
So Jesus went with him. A*p large crowd followed and pressed around him.
And a woman was there who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years.
She had suffered a great deal under the care of many doctors and had spent all she had, yet instead of getting better she grew worse.
When she heard about Jesus, she came up behind him in the crowd and touched his cloak,
because she thought, “If I just touch his clothes, I will be healed.”
Immediately her bleeding stopped and she felt in her body that she was freed from her suffering.
At*p once Jesus realized that power had gone out from him. He turned around in the crowd and asked, “Who*r touched*r my*r clothes?”*r
“You*p see the people crowding against you,” his disciples answered, “and yet you can ask, ‘Who*r touched*r me?’”*r
But*p Jesus kept looking around to see who had done it.
Then the woman, knowing what had happened to her, came and fell at his feet and, trembling with fear, told him the whole truth.
He said to her, “Daughter,*r your*r faith*r has*r healed*r you.*r Go*r in*r peace*r and*r be*r freed*r from*r your*r suffering.”*r
While*p Jesus was still speaking, some people came from the house of Jairus, the synagogue leader. “Your daughter is dead,” they said. “Why bother the teacher anymore?”
Overhearing*p what they said, Jesus told him, “Don’t*r be*r afraid;*r just*r believe.”*r
He*p did not let anyone follow him except Peter, James and John the brother of James.
When they came to the home of the synagogue leader, Jesus saw a commotion, with people crying and wailing loudly.
He went in and said to them, “Why*r all*r this*r commotion*r and*r wailing?*r The*r child*r is*r not*r dead*r but*r asleep.”*r
But they laughed at him. After*p he put them all out, he took the child’s father and mother and the disciples who were with him, and went in where the child was.
He took her by the hand and said to her, “Talitha*ir koum!”*ir (which means “Little*r girl,*r I*r say*r to*r you,*r get*r up!”).*r
Immediately the girl stood up and began to walk around (she was twelve years old). At this they were completely astonished.
He gave strict orders not to let anyone know about this, and told them to give her something to eat.
Mark 6
A Prophet Without Honor
Jesus*p left there and went to his hometown, accompanied by his disciples.

When the Sabbath came, he began to teach in the synagogue, and many who heard him were amazed. “Where*p did this man get these things?” they asked. “What’s this wisdom that has been given him? What are these remarkable miracles he is performing?
Isn’t this the carpenter? Isn’t this Mary’s son and the brother of James, Joseph, Judas and Simon? Aren’t his sisters here with us?” And they took offense at him.
Jesus*p said to them, “A*r prophet*r is*r not*r without*r honor*r except*r in*r his*r own*r town,*r among*r his*r relatives*r and*r in*r his*r own*r home.”*r
He could not do any miracles there, except lay his hands on a few sick people and heal them.
He was amazed at their lack of faith.
Jesus Sends Out the Twelve
Then*p Jesus went around teaching from village to village.
Calling the Twelve to him, he began to send them out two by two and gave them authority over impure spirits.
These*p were his instructions: “Take*r nothing*r for*r the*r journey*r except*r a*r staff—no*r bread,*r no*r bag,*r no*r money*r in*r your*r belts.*r
